text: all right so my name is Indra and I'm
here to talk about this thing I made it
with a friend of mine his name is Henrik
he's not here today but if you want
imagine what it looks like he's got a
big red beard I'll show you some photos
in a few slides the thing is that this
box has been way up into like way above
the clouds and then it fell back down
onto the earth and we recovered it and
this is sorry about that you know how
that went about and the thing is that in
the early 2010 a lot of nerds started
sending all sort of tech trash into near
space and it was old cell phones with
hacked serial interfaces Arduinos and
all sorts of amateur electronics that
they would wire together and basically
send up into the air with a weather
balloon the reason why they did this
what that they could actually reach the
stratosphere which is between 10 and 50
thousand metres altitude and if you have
a camera attached to that you can get
some really amazing footage we really
wanted to do this ourselves we wanted to
get our own pictures so we could brag on
the internet which is very important I'm
a software guy he's a hardware guy and
we figured we could do something
together so we bought a balloon and we
got a lot of stuff ready and then
basically just four years passed and
nothing happened that's usually how
projects go and so four years later we
sort of reconnect I'm in a different
part of the country we're not talking as
much he's got a girlfriend that he's
moved in with and he's gonna have a
child and we're realizing that we don't
have a lot of time so we have to to to
set some new objectives and get started
to actually be able to finish this so we
set some goals that we want to make
everything from scratch
no old cell phones and no we didn't want
to follow the same recipe that everyone
else was doing we wanted to reach 30,000
meters altitude and we wanted to be able
to recover it and finally prove that the
earth is flat and this is the device
that we made or other Hendrik made
because he is a hardware genius
I made the the bird so this is basically
two devices based on
same PCB card and it's got a GPS module
a logging module so that we can keep the
position stored locally on the card if
we lost contact it has a GSM module to
send text messages a lorry radio to
communicate with us back on earth and
also as a backup it had a beam signal we
could use so that if we were to approach
it physically we could point out the
direction in which to go in addition to
that we needed a lot of stuff back on
earth we set up everything yourself
servers with api's web apps we made an
Android application to act as an SMS
gateway and a lot of scripts and hacks
to make all of this to do to basically
work and talk together in a decent way
and the basic idea was to use Laura as
the main transport for communication you
may know Laura as an IOT protocol that's
basically for using wide area networks
where you would have multiple gateways
put around the city and they would act
as a gateway that would relay the
message to another network typically the
internet but in our case we wanted to
use the same technology but we couldn't
use the wide area network because we
were basically tens of thousands of
meters up in the air so we wanted to use
Laura but as with a point-to-point radio
so the munion device as we called it
we'd send directly to our own gateway
and then send the data to our private
network and the idea was that when we
had clear line of sites Laura would be
the main transport and as the payload
will descend and go behind vegetation
and buildings we would no longer be able
to contact it directly when the GSM
module would take over and send text
messages with the position so we would
have contacts 100% of the way we also
have the web application where we could
track it live and we also had friends
and colleagues who were following live
as it was happening and for those who
are unfamiliar with weather balloons
it's basically just a huge latex balloon
that you inflate with helium and then
you have a parachute attached to
and of course the payload and what
happens is basically that the the
balloon will ascend until a point where
it will just keep inflating and and
increase in size until it explodes and
the payload will start falling which
will cause the parachute to to open and
hopefully make the payload land
carefully back on earth and if you're
lucky you might even be able to find it
afterwards we had a GoPro knockoff
camera on board because we wanted to get
some really cool video footage we didn't
want to splurge on proper original GoPro
because we weren't really sure if we
would be able to actually recover it
here's just a few photos from the final
preparations we basically just stayed up
all night we wrote a few lines of codes
just minutes before we launched it
basically and we we were pretty
confident if not we were pretty
confident that it would be okay and on
the final launch day we're smiling and
we're always wearing protective goggles
very important we're smiling in this
picture but actually it didn't really go
all that well like we messed up a lot of
stuff and the most like the worst thing
we did was probably to pierce the
balloon which is the worst thing that
can happen to a balloon basically and to
make sure that it didn't like it was
losing a lot of helium so we had to duct
tape it layers and layers of duct tape
and then we just had to rush to get it
up before it loses too much helium we
also had way too much helium in it
probably like one kilogram of excess
lift which is a lot and the GPS module
seemed to stop working above 10,000
meters so basically what happened was
that he would go up and ascend to some
point around 10,000 meters we would
still be in in touch with the device it
will sit still be sending messages to us
but it would have no idea where it was
we would just get the same positions all
over again for maybe an hour so until it
was below 10,000 meters again but it did
actually come down again it did land
gracefully however it did land on the
middle of a mountain basically in a
swamp I'm going to show you some
pictures of the recovery the most fun
part was probably tracking it we drove
around following it we had an antenna
stuck on the top of the roof of the car
and then we could sit with a laptop
inside the car and basically just see as
it was coming down on a map and we could
just see getting closer and closer to
the swamp that was like between there
was a huge forest there was the swamp
and then it was a lake so the best of
the three options was was actually the
swamp so we were actually hoping it
would land there as we're getting closer
to it we were using the beam signal to
sort of find the direction of the device
which was kind of useless but it made
some really fun you know beep noises so
we kept using it and as we got closer we
could see something in the distance
something red and white over there and
that's actually the parachute and as we
got closer we could find it all laying
out in perfect glory quite happy like
you can't really tell from the photos
but it's really wet like it but getting
there was a real pain but at least we
didn't land over in the trees there and
we didn't land in the lake so we're
quite happy about that on the left side
you can see the parachute on the middle
side you can see the remains of the
balloon and on the right side you can
see this box here so we rushed over to
it because we really wanted to see some
of the amazing video footage that we had
captured with the camera this is what we
dreamed about this is what we got so
basically the the SD card was full of
corrupt files we were never able to
recover it so we don't have any video or
any sort of documentation from the
actual journey I said that we did use a
lot of duct tape this is basically all
that was left of the balloon we
recovered it a big chunk of duct tape
but in the end we did probably reach
around 20 to 20 2600 meters
and the reason why we know that is that
we had some barometric pressure sensors
onboard so we're not we can't say it
with 100% certainty but we probably
reached about 20 2600 meters and we also
reached about minus 35 degrees Celsius
which probably killed off the camera we
did stay in touch with the device for
100% of the time Henriques kid now and
we're best friends again
and in conclusion if you want to
reconnect with a long-lost friend you
should start a projects it's a great way
to get especially for guys who don't
talk much you'll have something to talk
about and argue about a lot always use
original GoPro cameras the home skimp
out on the cheap cameras avoid sharp
scissors when working with helium
balloons and finally we don't have any
evidence that proves otherwise so as far
as we're concerned the earth is flats
thank you
